title.narrative: Tanzania, United Republic of: Targeted country assistance
Tanzanie (la République-Unie de): Aide ciblée aux pays

description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

"VIMS WMS Data used by IVD for planning and continuous improvement ? Migration of data and Hosting of VIMS WMS servers by MOHCDGEC ? System Support tools"

target.value: Transfer of Ownership to Operate and maintain

comment.narrative: Data use of WMS and complete transition is completed, IVD are using VIMS WMS Stock status report extracted every week. Users have been created according to their roles and rights; 1. VIMS was successfully installed and tested in IVD servers. IVD had planned to purchase another server with higher specs and employ system admin and developers who will work closely with JSI to clone VIMS data to the new servers; 1. Development of WMS and VIMS user support manuals for both mainland and Zanzibar

title.narrative: 5 low performing regions achieving quality benchmarks (distribution completeness & updated ledgers) in preceding 6 months;

target.value: 7. Support Effective Vaccine Management Assessments (EVMA) preparation and implementation

comment.narrative: Due to COVID-19 priority, the EVMA has been scheduled for December 5th - 19th 2021 by IVD. Our team will participate in the preparation for the assessment and assist in the data collection and analysis.

title.narrative: LTWG meetings convened and demonstrated to be using EIS data regularly in past 6 months

target.value: 6. Support National level in supply chain monitoring through data use (On job training and supporting Logistics TWG sub-committee meetings)

comment.narrative: Due to competing priorities, the LTWG meetings were not conducted as planned. Meetings are tentatively scheduled for November, December, and January. We will continue to support through the NCE.

title.narrative: Increase in reporting through RTM and TImR in 5 low performing regions

target.value: 4. Monitoring and Maintenance visits to support RTM and TImR use in low performing regions

comment.narrative: In the process of increasing reporting rate through RTM and TImR in 5 low performing regions, the team participated in monitoring and maintenance field activities in 4 regions, including Rukwa, Katavi, Kilimanjaro and Mwanza. 1 region (Mtwara region) to be visited in December 2021.

title.narrative: 5 low performing regions trained in triangulating stock, CCE and performance data to prepare monthly needs

target.value: 5. Capacity building for subnational levels in forecasting and triangulating stock and vaccination data in VIMS (by contributing to Mid-Level Manager training, New comers training, CCE Technician training and development of immunization mentorship packages)

comment.narrative: New immunization staffs including DIVOs and RIVOs were included in this Vaccine Management and technologies orientation workshop which took place in Dodoma for 10days in November 2021.Other HSS activities were not implemented due to commitment to COVID 19 acceleration plan. In the TWG meeting held November 2021, it was agreed to integrate Routine Immunization activities with COVID 19 second phase plans. IVD will also revisit their annual work plan and ensure Partners' activities will be integrated.

title.narrative: Data improvement field activity implemented in 5 low performing Regions

target.value: 3. Support EIS data quality improvement at national and subnational levels. JSI staff participation and co-facilitation in Immunization performance review session at subnational levels, districts immunization performance evaluation meetings (EPI parliament), Immunization Technical Working Group (TWG) meetings, ICC and Annual Immunization Evaluation meeting as planned in IVD annual plan

comment.narrative: Not all immunization performance evaluation meetings were conducted as planned in the IVD annual plan. We will continue to support through the NCE. The team has participated in data improvement field activities to improve consistency of data in VIMS, RTM, DHIS2 and TImR in total number 5 low performing regions. 4 regions have been visited, including Rukwa, Katavi, Kilimanjaro and Mwanza. 1 region (Mtwara region) is to be visited in December 2021.

title.narrative: Documentation of lessons learnt from efforts to improve consistency of data in VIMS, RTM, DHIS2 and TImR in 5 low performing regions

target.value: 2. Support IVD in monitoring and troubleshooting EIS integration

comment.narrative: The team has documented lessons learnt from efforts to improve the consistency of data in VIMS, RTM, DHIS2 and TImR in 5 low performing regions. The IVD system review - Proposal for resolution was well documented showing action plans and timeline.

comment.narrative: WMS issue vouchers for quarterly requisitions have more than 90% consistency of data when compared to MSD invoices.

title.narrative: WHO : Data
e-Surveillance platform implemented

target.value: Support Strengtherning of Measles and Rubella case based surveillance and documentation of progress towards elimination
Support Strengtherning of Measles and Rubella case based surveillance and documentation of progress towards elimination

comment.narrative: WHO has supported the country to implement activities for measles elimination. this includes support to routine immunization, conduct supplementary immunization and measles case based surveillance. For the year 2020, the vaccination coverage for MR1 was 99% and MR2 being 83% a drop from 88% in the year 2019. the reason was due to shortage of MR vaccine. WHO has supported documentation of progress towards measles elimination.Tanzania NVC members and secretariate had a session at Morogoro Hotel for three days (8 -10/04/2021) for finalization of measles elimination progress report. Assessment of population immunity and progress toward elimination of measles was done through reviewing of records. The population profile of measles immunity among residents aged 0 through 19 years was developed and compared this profile to the distribution of measles cases across different age groups. Results: Although the country has maintained high coverage over the years, there are variations of immunization performance observed at sub-national levels with some achieved the coverage of below 90%. Additionally, despite a promising improved coverage of Measles/Rubella second dose (MR2) over years, the number of Measles/Rubella unimmunized children is still high countrywide. In the period of 2017 to 2020, Measles case-based surveillance indicators have been on track to achieve target. At national level, the country has attained Non-Measles -Non-Rubella rate (N-MR FRI Rate) of 2.0 and the number of reported suspected measles rubella cases has increased. Recommendation and Conclusion: Measles immunity need to be increased through advocating uptake of MR2 among eligible children. The NVC still anticipate low measles immunity in both infants and children between 0 and 5 years since cases predominantly occur in these two age groups.

title.narrative: Data desk review or triangulation analysis performed (coverage, surveillance, operational, others)

target.value: Provide technical support, participate and facilitate in the 2020 data review and harmonization, triangulation at National, Regional and District level before completion of the WHO/UNICEF JRF

comment.narrative: The process of JRF completion involves stakeholders from within MOHCDGEC-Mainland, Zanzibar, and partners. This activity was conducted in two sessions starting from 06th ? 16th April 2021. Session 1: Compilation of eJRF main document. The First session was used to develop eJRF main form which was done first in the downloaded excel file which was later transferred to electronic form in the WHO portal. eJRF form is divided into 19 sheets which captures country administrative profile, VPD cases and surveillance, immunization country profile, Logistics and supplies, communication, immunization pogramme management, vaccination coverage and general performance. Each form was assigned to a specific group according to thematic areas. This work was later presented to plenary where inputs were received from participants. Source of information used was from reported administrative data in EIS, DHIS-2, Surveys reports, and other related source of information. This year, eJRF form also came with COVD-19 vaccination readiness form. For Tanzania, we did not have any response on CIVD-19 vaccine as the country is awaiting assigned technical committee?s recommendations. Session 2: Development and Compilation of DIP and annual desk review. Joint report form submission requires updated annual desk review analysis, Data Improvement plan, Hw?s vaccinations form. DIP document highlight country?s plans to improve quality of routine reported data. It supposed to be updated every year. Data desk review analysis monitors performance of routine immunization and surveillance indicators while HW?s vaccination form collects details on plans and status of vaccination to health care workers. These documents were finalized and shared with IVD technical working group for more inputs. OUTCOMES OF THIS ACTIVITY: The team successfully managed to finalize eJRF document in country portal, which was reviewed and approved at country level and now awaits external reviews.

title.narrative: Data Improvement Plan (DIP) developed

target.value: Provide technical support, participate and facilitate in the 2020 data review and harmonization, triangulation at National, Regional and District level before completion of the WHO/UNICEF JRF

comment.narrative: WHO provided technical and financial support to conduct a workshop from 13th to 15th April 2021. The main objective of the workshop was to harmonize immunization data for the period of January to December 2020 from TiMR, VIMS, DHIS, IDSR and other programme data and preparation of data improvement plan and annual report in electronic WHO/UNICEF joint reporting form ready for submission to WHO AFRO. Specific Objectives includes ? To review the immunization data from all sources for the purpose of doing data cleaning and harmonization prior to the development of electronic JRF report ? To monitor that state of completeness, validity, consistency, timeliness and accuracy of surveillance and immunization coverage data at national level ? To identify problems with data quality through a process of data cleaning and verification with respective councils and health facilities ? To ensure the harmonization of laboratory and case-based surveillance databases ? Develop draft electronic JRF report and data improvement plan. The workshop involved all immunization stakeholders including; MoHCDGEC (IVD, HMIS, IDSR) PORALG, WHO, CHAI, JSI and representative of the Regional Immunization and Vaccine Officers (RIVOs) and Representative of the District Immunization Officers from the region (DIVOs) Accomplished: 1. Immunization data cleaning and harmonization exercise was successful conducted, and feedback provided to the regions and councils for future improvements on data quality. 2. Draft electronic WHO/UNICEF Joint Report Form for Immunization was developed based on the standard templates and guidance provided by WHO and UNICEF regional Office. 3. Draft Data Improvement Plan was agreed and the small team to work on the advancement of the draft was formed. The agreed timeline for the finalization of the data improvement plan is end of April before the final submission of the JRF report.

title.narrative: WHO : Health Financing/Sustainability
Medium-term costed strategic plan for immunisation (National Immunisation Strategy) developed by MOH/EPI and integrated with national health strategy (country-led, with a capacity building component)

target.value: Support Zanzibar to develop 2021-2025 National Immunization Strategy (NIS)

comment.narrative: The Ministry of Health -Zanzibar needs to develop NIS/cMYP in order to ensure all the national, regional and global plans for ensuring the benefit of vaccines is achieved by all in order to attain sustainable development goals and guidance to the immunization programme is maintained. Rationale for developing NIS/cMYP 1. To support Ministry responsible for health in Zanzibar to define five-year goals and develop a roadmap for achieving the objectives. 2. The NIS will be aligned with the global IA2030 and national health strategic plan IV and it is expected that NIS will have a vision to address the immunization challenges in all target population especially for the emerging diseases and hence protect against vaccines preventable diseases. 3. The NIS will also be used as the advocacy tool in ensuring sustainable vaccination services. 4. Lastly, the tool will be used to secure resources for promoting immunization services both domestically and internationally. There has been a major delay in developing this strategy due to competing priorities especially those related to responding to COVID-19 outbreak. With the support of consultant, the development of the NIS will be done through the programme documents review and national dialogues (workshops/meetings) with stakeholders in each of the following stages; a) Situational analysis and EPI review b) Setting goals, objectives, strategies and roadmap for action c) Identify resources requirement and advise the Ministry responsible for health to conduct budget negotiation for the developed strategy d) Developing monitoring and evaluation system e) Approval and endorsement of NIS

target.value: Conduct training and support bottleneck analysis for delivering immunization services in urban areas (DSM and Unguja) and planning process using REC approach.

comment.narrative: Activity not started due to COVID-19 situation in Dar es salaam region. Planned to be conducted before September 2021

target.value: Conduct training and support bottleneck analysis for delivering immunization services in urban areas (DSM and Unguja) and planning process using REC approach.

comment.narrative: Dar es Salaam region is providing immunization services in all districts with the view to improving access and quality immunization services to every eligible child. By implementing the comprehensive council plans with components of delivering immunization services, every council is expected to attain immunization coverage of 90% or more of all antigens. Though the national EPI programme adopted the RED/REC approach since many years ago, not all the districts are able to achieve the expected 90% or more coverage every year. A review of immunization coverage data from 2015 to 2020 shows that between 10-30% of targeted children (0-11 months) do not receive their third dose of penta3 annually. The districts mostly affected with large number of under vaccinated with MR2 children for the year 2020 are Temeke (6126), Ilala (6094) and Kinondoni (4756). There are also high immunization dropout (penta1-penta3) rates in these same districts that account for low coverage (Source DSM Annual EPI data 2015-2020). There is also significant population movement in cities; slum populations and other people living in poverty in urban areas can be particularly fluid with considerable in and out-migration. Poor urban dwellers and slum populations can also be particularly diverse in comparison with more stable rural populations, leading to additional challenges in social cohesion, communication and health seeking behavior. For these reasons, existing RI assessment mechanisms require adaptation or possible replacement to work effectively in impoverished urban settings. The concerns about the persistent low immunization coverage in 3 councils of DSM generated interests for rapid assessments of the immunization programme in DSM in collaboration with the EPI programme in selected districts to understand the reasons for poor immunization performance and plan for improvement. There has been major delay in implementing this activity due to intense transmission of COVID-19 in DSM

In the period of 2017 to 2020, Measles case-based surveillance indicators have been on track to achieve target. The NVC still anticipate low measles immunity in both infants and children between 0 and 5 years since cases predominantly occur in these two age groups.

title.narrative: WHO : Service Delivery
Service delivery related barriers of missed communities to access immunisation services identified and prioritized

target.value: Support Strengthening of routine immunization with focus on increasing uptake of MCV2 vaccine

comment.narrative: WHO is support MoH to strengthen routine immunization especially in low performing district. The activity was launched by the Minister of health during African vaccination week on 27th April 2021. Overall Objective The overall objective is to support low performing councils to identify key challenges for low performance and strengthen routine immunization through implementation of PIRI. Specific Objectives 1. To identify low performing councils based on routine data, coverage survey and MR zero dose collected during 2019 IMRC. 2. To identify key challenges for relatively low immunization performance in the respective council 3. To set and implement strategies (including PIRI) to address the key identified challenges ? Identification of the Low performing councils The country aimed at identifying the lower preforming councils (based on both routine data, coverage survey data and MR zero dose data collected during 2019 IMRC) and assess the reason for low performance and implement high impact interventions with the use of PIRI. The map below shows the low performing councils. ? Identification of Challenges and Set Strategy Although the aim of the support is to implement PIRI approach, but other strategies will be set based on the key identified challenges in a specific region/council. The team from National and Regional level will facilitate the process of setting strategy and the councils and health facility levels will be fully involved to ensure the set strategy are realistic and implementable. The developed tools will be used to assess the gaps in key immunization thematic areas (including; Planning and Management, Service delivery, Demand creation and Social Mobilization and Data Management) areas which will guide the set strategy. The implementation of the identified strategic actions will be tailored to the council moreover all councils identified will implement PIRI.

target.value: Support mapping of Zero dose children and set strategies to vaccinate all eligible children in selected regions-SSA officer to be embedded in IVD for 60% of the time and WHO office 40%

comment.narrative: WHO supported the MoH in conducting data desk review for 2020 district performance data and identify areas will large number of unvaccinated children. The number of Measles/Rubella under-vaccinated children has increased from 233,304 in 2019 to 357,534 in 2020, an increment of 53% . There was huge variation on Measles/Rubella under-vaccinated children across districts in 2020 whereby 18 districts had more than 5000 Measles/Rubella under-vaccinated children . This has increased from 7% in 2019 to 9% in 2020. The number of districts with MCV1 coverage below 80% increased from 9 (5%) districts in 2019 to 16 (8%) districts in 2020. Further, the number of districts with MCV1 coverage of 90% or above dropped from 157 (81%) districts in 2019 to 153 (78%) districts in 2020. This can be attributed by inconsistency availability of MR vaccines across the districts. All the identified districts were targeted for PIRI during African vaccination week and beyond. Tools have been prepared, printed and disseminated to all targeted districts.

title.narrative: Service delivery approach suitable to reach missed communities identified and endorsed

target.value: Support Strengthening of routine immunization with focus on increasing uptake of MCV2 vaccine

comment.narrative: In 2014, Tanzania introduced MCV2 given at the age of 18 months into the Routine immunization and in 2018. There are several initiatives led by the Ministry of Health through the support of partners including Gavi, WHO, UNICEF, CHAI, JSI, Jhpiego, PATH and others to strengthen immunization system and address the key challenges identified by the program. The initiatives include; Introduction of Electronic Immunization System, improving Warehouse Management of Vaccines and related supplies at National and subnational levels, capacity building of health workers on different key thematic areas and provision of technical support in implementation of various activities. Given the fact that Tanzania has maintained high vaccination coverages over the years and the fact that some of the regions and councils are not performing well based on the administrative data and Periodic Intensification of routine immunization in these scenarios is necessary to boost routine coverage. It is also important for the country to identify key challenges for low performance and set and implement strategies to address the identified challenges. The overall objective is to support low performing councils to identify key challenges for low performance and strengthen routine immunization through implementation of PIRI. Specific Objectives 1. To identify low performing councils based on 2020 routine immunization coverage data, coverage survey and MR zero dose collected Measles rubella case based surveillance and estimated of children unvaccinated with second dose of MCV. 2. To identify key challenges for relatively low immunization performance in the respective council 3. To set and implement strategies (including PIRI) to address the key identified challenges Methodologies ? Identification of the Low performing councils ? Identification of Challenges and Set Strategy ? Implementation and Monitoring & Evaluation The total budget for the activity is equivalent to US$132,762

title.narrative: PATH
MOH ICT team enabled to perform customization of TimR software back end independently from PATH support

target.value: OBJECTIVE3: Build the capacity of the MOHCDGEC ICT in-house development team in TimR software maintenance and customization.

comment.narrative: Since 2018, PATH through TCA have been training the MOH ICT team on TimR software management including integration with other system, hosting and infrastructure management as well as software customization. However, the training and capacity building initiative have not translated into the team taking active role in supporting software management roles. In Q2 this year, MOH ICT team hired and seconded four staff with software administration and management skillsets to provide support to IVD electronic information systems (EIS). Path has been actively working with the team to building their capacity of TimR software management through trainings, mentorship and engagement into ongoing customization activities. The team is apparently able and is managing all software administrative and infrastructure management roles which is key for total ownership of the TimR solution .

title.narrative: Integration of BRS4G and TimR implemented and demonstrated at scale in one region selected by MOH

target.value: OBJECTIVE4: Provide technical capacity and linkages of the TimR system and the country?s CRVS system for improved denominator of the children to be immunized.

comment.narrative: The team was able to identify and document the requirements for the integration and testing was done but during the testing, it was realized that RITA made some changes that also will need to be impacted in TImR for integration to function better. So those changes were identified, PATH team with IVD technical team are currently working on accommodating those new changes, after those changes are implemented RITA technical team and IVD will meet for another round of testing, after testing is completed it will be demonstrated to IVD and RITA management team before testing to Health facilities. Finalization of preparations and demonstration in one district in Morogoro region is ongoing and has been planned to take place not later than January 2022. Morogoro was selected as a test site to easy the process of providing support when needed as well as the fact that both TImR and Under-five birth Registration system are in place with reasonable degree of usability and maturity.
